questions.text: A 7-year-old male was brought to OPD by his mother with reduced hearing since 2 months. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane was observed as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Myringitis Bullosa

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous otitis media: (glue ear) cases present with hearing loss and mild ear ache. Otoscopy reveals fluid level and air bubbles.

 

 

Option B. Acute otitis media: Patients present with ear ache, fever, ear discharge. Following image shows red and bulging TM.

 

 

Option D. Myringitis Granulosa: Patient usually presents with painless otorrhea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringitis Bullosa should be considered when a patient presents with the acute onset of ear pain accompanied by visible blisters on the tympanic membrane, particularly in the context of a recent upper respiratory infection or influenza-like illness. Management focuses on pain relief and monitoring for resolution, with antibiotics or antivirals tailored to the underlying cause if identified.

questions.text: Anterior ethmoidal sinus drains into: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle meatus

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary sinus and frontal sinus, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. The middle meatus is a crucial drainage pathway for these sinuses, allowing mucus to flow from the sinuses into the nasal cavity. This drainage is essential for maintaining sinus health and preventing infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, not the ethmoidal sinuses.

 

Option C. Superior meatus: The superior meatus is the drainage site for the posterior ethmoidal sinus.

 

Option D. Nasal cavity: This is a general term and does not specify the precise drainage pathway for the anterior ethmoidal sinus, which specifically drains into the middle meatus.

 

Additionally, the sphenoid sinuses drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary and frontal sinuses, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: CSF otorrhea can occur in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Temporal Bone fracture

 

CSF otorrhea is associated with Longitudinal Temporal Bone fracture.

 

Temporal bone fractures can be of types:

 

 

 

Battle’s sign is associated with temporal bone fracture.

 

 

Cribriform plate damage can lead to CSF rhinorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TM rupture due to trauma: While traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane may occur, it does not typically result in CSF otorrhea unless associated with a temporal bone fracture.

 

Option B. Stab injury in the eye: Unlikely to cause CSF otorrhea directly unless there is extensive cranial trauma involving the skull base.

 

Option C. Cribriform plate fracture: More commonly associated with CSF rhinorrhea (leakage of CSF from the nose) due to its location and relationship to the nasal cavity and sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF otorrhea is a serious condition often linked with fractures of the temporal bone. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent complications and promote effective healing. Monitoring for signs of infection or persistent leakage is essential, as these may necessitate more aggressive interventions.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

 

  • Among the given options, electron microscopy will be the least useful in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance.
  • Electron microscopy -  can detect structural and functional abnormalities of cilia but do not detect any other abnormalities interfering with nasal mucociliary clearance. It is used to visualize the detailed architecture of cilia, which can help identify defects in ciliary structure responsible for impaired mucociliary transport, but it does not measure the actual transport or clearance function.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saccharin Test: This is a straightforward clinical test where a small amount of saccharin is placed on the nasal mucosa, and the time it takes for the subject to taste the sweetness is measured. This time reflects the mucociliary clearance rate.

 

Option C. Charcoal Powder Method: Involves placing a small amount of charcoal powder in the nose and timing how long it takes for it to appear in the pharynx, similarly assessing the clearance capability of the mucociliary apparatus.

 

Option D. Scintigraphy: This nuclear medicine test uses a small amount of radioactive material to track and record mucociliary transport and clearance, providing both functional and anatomical information about the nasal and sinus mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Test for mucociliary clearance is:
    • Saccharin with or without color test in vivo -   Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
    • Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
    • Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
    • Nasal nitric oxide -  Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
    • Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
    • Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
    • The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: The following image shows which X-ray view?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Towne’s view

 

Based on the image provided, where the X-ray beam is directed from above the skull at an angle and the detector is positioned below the skull, the indicated X-ray view is consistent with the Towne’s view.

 

Towne’s view is an X-ray where the beam is angled at approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and directed downward toward the patient's head, which is positioned with the chin lifted. This view is particularly useful for assessing the occipital bone, posterior fossa, and foramen magnum, as well as the mastoid and middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view is an X-ray taken with the patient's head tilted backward so that the X-ray beam is directed perpendicularly to the orbitomeatal line. It's often used to visualize the maxillary sinuses, the orbits, and the nasal cavity.

 

Option B. Caldwell view is performed with the patient’s head positioned such that the X-ray beam is angled at 15-20 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and the central ray is directed towards the nose. This view is used to visualize the frontal sinuses, orbits, and ethmoid sinuses.

 

Option D. Schuller’s view is an X-ray that provides a lateral view of the skull, specifically to evaluate the mastoid air cells and the structure of the temporal bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Towne’s view X-ray is used to visualize the occipital bone, posterior fossa, foramen magnum, and mastoid process by positioning the patient with the head tilted upward and the X-ray beam angled approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a past history of intubation presents to the OPD with shortness of breath that began during play, approximately 2 months after the intubation. A radiograph of the chest is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Croup

 

Explanation: 


The presentation suggests croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis) because:

 

  • X-ray shows characteristic "steeple sign" (subglottic narrowing)
  • Age group is typical (6 months to 3 years)
  • History of recent intubation could predispose to viral infection

  • Clinical features match with croup: 

    • Gradual onset of respiratory distress
    • Inspiratory stridor
    • Usually caused by parainfluenza virus types I & II
    • Submucosal edema causes narrowing in subglottic region

     

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Acute epiglottitis

 

  • Shows "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray
  • More severe, rapid onset
  • Typically caused by H. influenzae
  • Child prefers sitting position (tripod sign)

 

 

Option C. Laryngomalacia

 

  • Most common congenital anomaly of larynx
  • Shows omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy
  • Symptoms improve in prone position
  • Present from birth

 

 

Option D. Bronchitis

 

  • Lower airway inflammation
  • No characteristic "steeple sign"
  • Different radiological findings
  • Usually presents with cough as primary symptom

 

Educational Objective: 

 

"steeple sign" on chest/neck X-ray as characteristic of croup, representing subglottic narrowing.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presented in ENT OPD with hoarseness of voice following a quarrel in public. On laryngoscopy, the following picture is seen. Management of this patient is? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MLS removal

 

Explanation:

 

The laryngoscopic image shows a unilateral large mass at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, which is consistent with a vocal polyp. Vocal polyps typically result from vocal abuse or trauma and can cause hoarseness of voice. The definitive management of a vocal polyp is Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS) removal, which involves surgically excising the polyp to restore normal voice function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not indicated for benign lesions such as vocal polyps. It is used primarily for malignant conditions.

 

Option C. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is not a standard treatment for vocal polyps. It is more commonly used for other types of lesions.

 

Option D. Voice rest & Speech therapy: Voice rest and speech therapy are generally recommended for vocal nodules, which are smaller and often bilateral. While these therapies can help in reducing strain on the vocal cords, they are not the primary treatment for vocal polyps, which require surgical removal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The management of a vocal polyp, which presents as a unilateral mass on the vocal cord, is surgical removal via Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS). Voice rest and speech therapy are more suitable for smaller, bilateral vocal nodules.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The presentation of a child with a type B tympanometry curve indicates the likelihood of serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy as the underlying cause.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: While this can relieve middle ear effusion, it does not address the underlying adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Similar to grommet insertion alone, this option does not address the root cause of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: This procedure involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid but does not address the cause or provide a lasting solution like adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the most appropriate management for a child presenting with serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy, addressing both the immediate symptoms and underlying cause.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia. On further evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and episodes of epilepsy were observed. A CT scan of the brain was performed What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal abscess

 

Explanation: 


The presentation indicates temporal lobe abscess because:

 

  • Clear space-occupying lesion in temporal lobe visible on CT
  • Classic symptoms of temporal lobe involvement: 
    • Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement
    • Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression
    • Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • Common complication of CSOM due to: 
    • Direct extension through tegmen tympani

    • Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM

       

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Meningitis

 

  • Most common intracranial complication of CSOM
  • No discrete abscess formation on imaging
  • Shows meningeal enhancement
  • Different clinical features (neck rigidity, Kernig's sign)

 

Option C. Subdural abscess

 

  • Collection between dura and arachnoid
  • Different imaging appearance
  • No discrete parenchymal involvement
  • Different clinical presentation

 

Option D. Extradural abscess

 

  • Collection outside dura but intracranial
  • Different imaging appearance
  • Less severe neurological symptoms
  • No parenchymal involvement

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, presenting with seizures and characteristic CT findings of a space-occupying lesion in the temporal lobe.

questions.text: 14-year-old boy with recurrent profuse epistaxis and reddish mass in the nasal cavity: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) JNA (Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma)

 

A 14-year-old boy presenting with recurrent, profuse epistaxis (nosebleeds) and a reddish mass in the nasal cavity is highly suggestive of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). JNA is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. The hallmark symptoms include recurrent severe nosebleeds and nasal obstruction due to the tumor mass.

 

Key characteristics of JNA:

 

  • Occurs in adolescent males
  • Presents with recurrent, profuse epistaxis
  • Appears as a reddish mass in the nasal cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NPC (Nasopharyngeal carcinoma): Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is typically seen in older adults and is associated with risk factors like consumption of nitrosamine-rich foods (e.g., salted fish). It often presents with unilateral hearing loss due to Eustachian tube blockage, leading to serous otitis media. It is not common in adolescents and does not typically present with recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Polyp: Nasal polyps are benign growths in the nasal cavity that usually do not bleed. They can cause nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea but are not typically associated with recurrent, profuse epistaxis.

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Inverted papillomas are benign tumors that usually occur in older adults. They are associated with a risk of malignancy and often present with unilateral nasal obstruction and occasional bleeding but not the recurrent, profuse epistaxis seen in JNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) should be suspected in adolescent males who present with recurrent, profuse epistaxis and a reddish mass in the nasal cavity. This condition is characteristic of this age and gender group and requires specific clinical suspicion for accurate diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.text:
A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below:  (INICET Nov 2021)

 

 

Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient. (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

Based on the provided tympanogram findings, it is likely that the tuning fork tests for this patient would reveal a positive left Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the right ear (normal ear).

 

 

INTERPRETATION OF AUDIOGRAM

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap (AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.
  • In the question given above, left sided air conduction and bone conduction curves do not have any gap and they are occupying middle part of the graph. Hence, it is left SNHL.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear: This result would be expected in conductive hearing loss, not SNHL.

 

Option B. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This also indicates conductive hearing loss, which is not supported by the audiogram findings.

 

Option D. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This would indicate normal hearing or mild hearing loss in the right ear, which does not match the audiogram showing significant SNHL in the left ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne's test remains positive, and Weber's test lateralizes to the better-hearing ear. The provided audiogram indicates left-sided SNHL, resulting in a positive Rinne test on the left and Weber lateralizing to the right ear.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: For OME, Myringotomy is done in which quadrant? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antero-inferior

 

Explanation:

 

In Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), myringotomy is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. This location is specifically chosen because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding important structures. The antero-inferior quadrant is the safest area to make an incision as it avoids damage to the ossicles and other vital middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antero-posterior: No such quadrant exists.

 

Option C. Postero-superior: This is the most dangerous quadrant for myringotomy as it contains the incus and stapes. Additionally, the chorda tympani nerve runs through this area, and facial nerve injury is a risk if the incision extends too deeply. This area is avoided for routine myringotomy.

 

Option D. Postero-inferior: Although this quadrant is relatively safe compared to the postero-superior quadrant, it is not the preferred site for myringotomy. The round window niche is located in the posterior part of the middle ear, and damage to this structure could potentially affect inner ear function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringotomy for OME is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding vital middle ear structures, ensuring both effectiveness and safety of the procedure.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinusitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The CT image shows maxillary sinusitis because:

 

  • Clear hypodense thickening in the maxillary sinus
  • Involvement of maxillary sinus with mucosal thickening/opacification
  • Anatomical landmarks visible: 
    • Orbit above
    • Maxillary sinus below
    • Ethmoid cells medially
    • Cribriform plate superiorly
  • Disease appears to be spreading into nasal cavity, suggesting possible antrochoanal polyp

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Frontal sinusitis

 

  • Frontal sinuses not clearly visible in this cut
  • Would be located superior to orbits
  • Different radiological appearance

 

Option C. Ethmoidal sinusitis

 

  • Though ethmoid cells are visible medially
  • No significant pathology in ethmoid region
  • Would show opacification of ethmoid air cells

 

Option D. Sphenoidal sinusitis

 

  • Sphenoid sinus not visible in this cut
  • Would be seen at nasopharyngeal level
  • Located most posteriorly among all sinuses

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Most common in adults because ostium locates higher than floor level and drainage is against the gravity.
  • Pain over upper jaw present.

questions.text: Which of the following middle ear structure is a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot plate of stapes

 

The malleus, incus, and stapes are the three ossicles of the middle ear that transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. 

 

The footplate of the stapes is the portion of the stapes that sits in the oval window of the cochlea. It is unique among the ossicles because its development involves contributions from neural crest cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malleus: Develops from the first branchial (pharyngeal) arch, also known as Meckel's cartilage, which is not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option B. Stapes: While it is part of the same series of ossicles as the malleus, the main structure of the stapes develops from the second branchial (pharyngeal) arch, known as Reichert's cartilage, which is also not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option D. Incus: Like the malleus, is derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It too is not a derivative of neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The footplate of the stapes in the middle ear is the structure derived from neural crest cells, distinguishing it from the other ossicles (malleus and incus), which are derived from the first and second pharyngeal arches and not from neural crest cells.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Water’s view

 

Occipitomental view is also called Water's view.

 

Water's view: The patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward.

 

Structures seen in Water's view are:

 

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's view - Typically used for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum.

 

 

Structures seen – 

Arcuate eminence

Superior semicircular canal

Mastoid antrum

Internal auditory canal

Tympanic cavity

Cochlea

External auditory canal

 

Clinical application – Acoustic neuroma, Petrositis

 

Option C. Law's view - Generally related to imaging of the shoulder or elbow, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stenver's view - A radiographic projection used primarily for detailed imaging of the mastoid process and middle ear structures.

Structures seen –

Arcuate eminence

Internal auditory meatus

Labyrinth with vestibule

Mastoid antrum

Cochlea

Entire petrous pyramid

 

 

Educational Objective:


Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: Which of the following is the first investigation in newborn for audiological assessment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OAE (Otoacoustic Emissions)

 

OAE is the first choice for newborn hearing screening because:

 

  • It is a simple, quick, and non-invasive test
  • Can be done with a portable device
  • Involves placing a probe in the infant's ear that sends sound stimulus and captures emissions from outer hair cells
  • If result is "pass", indicates normal hearing
  • If result is "refer", then BERA is done as the next step
  • Tests the integrity of outer hair cells in the cochlea
  • Can be performed while baby is sleeping or quiet

Other Options:

 

Option A. BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry): Though essential for newborn screening, it is more complex and time-consuming than OAE. It is used as a second-line test if OAE results are abnormal.

Option B. PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry): Not suitable for newborns as it requires active participation and response from the subject, which newborns cannot provide.

 

Option D. Impedance: Not appropriate as first-line screening in newborns as it primarily tests middle ear function and requires some cooperation from the subject.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OAE is the first-line screening test for newborn hearing assessment due to its simplicity, speed, and non-invasive nature.

 

Newborn screening of hearing:

 

  • Here we test otoacoustic emissions (OAE) and brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA).
  • Outer hair cells in cochlea emit these very low intensity sounds (OAE) & they can be collected by a microphone kept in EAC.
  • Normal OAE means cochlear hair cells are functioning normally and cochlea is normally functioning.
  • BERA tests the integrity of auditory nerve (auditory pathway from cochlea to brain). It is an objective test.
    • Here we give a sound stimulus and check the electrical potentials that arise along the auditory pathway from cochlear nerve to brain.
    • Wave V is most prominent in BERA that corresponds to lateral lemniscus.
    • It is a non-invasive procedure. It is also an objective test (whereas PTA is a subjective test = result depends on the responses given by patient/subject).
  • Normal BERA means the cochlear nerve is intact and conducting sound impulses from cochlea to brain.
  • So, normal OAE and BERA will indicate an almost normal hearing pathway, hence used in newborn screening.
  • BERA is also used to check malingerers (people those who pretend deaf).

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. His CT scan is given. What could be the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation: 

 

The patient presents with symptoms including nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. The CT scan shows a mass involving the maxillary sinus. These clinical features are highly suggestive of maxillary sinus carcinoma. This condition often presents with such symptoms due to the tumor mass causing obstruction and local invasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This condition typically occurs in adolescent males and arises from the nasopharynx, not the maxillary sinus. It is characterized by severe epistaxis and nasal obstruction, but the patient's age and the location of the mass make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

 

Option C. Orbital Floor Fracture: Orbital floor fractures are best seen in coronal CT views and typically result from trauma. They present with symptoms such as diplopia, enophthalmos, and infraorbital anesthesia, but not with nasal obstruction and cheek swelling without trauma history.

 

Option D. Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis: This condition is seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes. It involves rapid tissue destruction, including the eyes and palate, leading to black necrotic tissue. The presentation of the patient does not fit this severe and aggressive infection.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maxillary sinus carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. Diagnosis is often confirmed through imaging, showing a mass in the maxillary sinus

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly damaged after parotid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

The Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid gland surgery due to its anatomical course through the gland. Damage to this nerve can result in facial paralysis or weakness, affecting expressions and other functions like eyelid closure and stapedius muscle reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Trigeminal nerve (Cranial Nerve V) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing. It is less commonly damaged during parotid surgery because of its location and the type of sensory and motor innervation it provides.

 

Option C. The Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX) is involved in taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue and swallowing. It is not typically at risk during parotid surgery as it does not traverse the parotid gland like the facial nerve.

 

Option D. The Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI) innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles and is not usually at risk during parotid surgery because it does not run through the parotid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Facial nerve is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid surgery due to its anatomical path through the parotid gland, making it vulnerable to injury during surgical procedures involving this gland

questions.text: On the promontory, behind the tympanic membrane, there is a red mass originating within the middle ear. CT is given. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

 

Explanation:

 

The CT scan shows a mass located on the promontory behind the tympanic membrane, which is typical of a glomus tympanicum, NOT glomus jugulare.

 

Key points:

 

  • Glomus tympanicum arises on the promontory along the course of Jacobson’s nerve (tympanic branch of IX cranial nerve).
  • It is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm.
  • It appears as a red mass behind the intact tympanic membrane, producing a pulsatile red reflex.
  • CT shows a soft tissue mass confined to the middle ear without erosion of the caroticojugular spine.
  • Glomus jugulare, in contrast, originates from the dome of the jugular bulb, grows into the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and typically erodes the caroticojugular spine (the “phelp sign”).

 

In CT image, there is no obvious erosion of the caroticojugular spine, and the mass is confined to the middle ear promontory, confirming glomus tympanicum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glomus jugulare: Incorrect here — because the tumour is limited to the middle ear promontory without signs of extension into the jugular bulb or jugular foramen. There is no caroticojugular spine erosion.

 

Option C. Otosclerosis: Does not appear as a mass. It causes abnormal bone deposition near the stapes, leading to conductive hearing loss but not a visible mass.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect — because the finding matches glomus tympanicum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A red mass on the promontory behind an intact tympanic membrane, with no erosion of the caroticojugular spine, indicates glomus tympanicum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window

 

The affected structure in high-frequency hearing loss is the basal turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the oval window.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy). Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central core of the cochlea around which the cochlear duct spirals. While important, it does not lie near the basal turn directly affected in high-frequency hearing loss.

 

Option B. Stria Vascularis: Located on the outer wall of the cochlear duct and is responsible for producing the endolymph. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph but is not located near the oval window.

 

Option D. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet, it is relevant for the transmission of lower frequency sounds, not high frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of high-frequency hearing loss, the basal turn of the cochlea near the oval window is typically involved. Understanding the anatomical proximity of the oval window to the basal turn helps in pinpointing the site of lesion and aids in specific diagnostic and therapeutic approaches aimed at the high-frequency hearing spectrum.

questions.text: In a prolonged intubation patient, the following is seen. Staging for this is given by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotton Meyer

 

The images depict subglottic stenosis, which is a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords, often due to prolonged intubation. This condition results from the high-pressure cuff of the endotracheal tube irritating the mucosa beneath the glottis. The Cotton Meyer classification system is used to stage subglottic stenosis based on the degree of airway narrowing:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radkowski: This staging system is used for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), not subglottic stenosis.

 

Option C. AJCC: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging is primarily used for cancer staging and does not apply to subglottic stenosis.

 

Option D. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for categorizing the extent of cancers, specifically focusing on tumor size (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M). It is not relevant for subglottic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Subglottic stenosis resulting from prolonged intubation is staged using the Cotton Meyer classification, which grades the severity based on the percentage of airway narrowing

 

  • Grade 1: 0-50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: 100% stenosis (complete obstruction)

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 -1 - 3 - 4- 5

 

The auditory pathway begins at the peripheral sensory receptors and progresses through a series of nuclei and tracts in the central nervous system before reaching the auditory cortex. The correct sequence from the periphery to the higher centers is:

 

  • Spiral ganglion (2): Located in Rosenthal's canal within the cochlea, the spiral ganglion contains bipolar neurons that send fibers through the cochlear nerve (part of the eighth cranial nerve) to the brainstem.
  • Cochlear nucleus (1): The first central auditory nucleus where the cochlear nerve fibers terminate.
  • Superior olivary nucleus (3): Serves as a major binaural processing center in the brainstem, crucial for localizing sounds in space.
  • Inferior colliculus (4): Acts as an important relay station in the midbrain, integrating auditory input before sending it to the thalamus.
  • Medial geniculate body (5): Part of the thalamus, this structure further processes auditory information before transmitting it to the auditory cortex.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve

  2. Cochlear Nucleus

  3. Superior Olivary nucleus

  4. Lateral lemniscus

  5. Inferior colliculus

  6. Medial geniculate body

  7. Auditory cortex

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 15

questions.text: What is the procedure being done in the image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stapedotomy

 

The image shows a stapedotomy procedure where:

 

  • The stapes suprastructure has been removed
  • A piston prosthesis is being inserted between the long process of incus and stapes footplate
  • A small fenestration is made in the footplate to connect middle ear with inner ear
  • This is the treatment of choice for otosclerosis where the stapes footplate is fixed in the oval window
  • The prosthesis restores the ossicular chain continuity and sound transmission

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This involves repairing the tympanic membrane perforation using temporalis fascia or tragal perichondrium graft. The image shows intervention at the level of stapes, not tympanic membrane.

 

Option C. Ossiculoplasty: While this involves reconstruction of ossicular chain, it specifically refers to reconstruction of malleus and incus using either autologous or prosthetic materials (TORP/PORP). The image shows specific intervention at stapes level.

 

Option D. Mastoidectomy: This involves drilling the mastoid bone behind the ear to remove diseased tissue/bone. The image shows middle ear surgery focused on stapes, not mastoid surgery.

 

Educational Objective:


Stapedotomy is the surgical procedure of choice for otosclerosis, involving removal of fixed stapes suprastructure and placement of a piston prosthesis to restore sound transmission.

questions.text: Indication for this incision: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open rhinoplasty

 

The image shows an incision along the columella and the nostrils, characteristic of an open rhinoplasty approach. In open rhinoplasty, this type of incision allows the surgeon to lift the skin over the nasal dorsum, providing direct visualization of the underlying bony and cartilaginous structures, including the alar cartilages and nasal bones. This approach is used for making precise adjustments to the shape of the external nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell luc: Caldwell-Luc surgery is a procedure primarily used for accessing the maxillary sinus. It involves making an incision in the gingivobuccal sulcus (inside the mouth) to enter the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall. This approach is not related to nasal dorsum access and does not involve incisions on the external nose.

 

 

Option B. Midfacial degloving: Midfacial degloving is a technique used for the removal of extensive nasopharyngeal tumors, such as juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas (JNA). It involves lifting the facial soft tissues, including the nasal mucosa, through incisions made intraorally. This method provides access to the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus but does not involve an incision like the one shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incision shown in the image is specific to open rhinoplasty, allowing direct access to the nasal structures for reshaping and reconstructive procedures.

choices.text: It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles.
Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin.
Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required.
Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about spasmodic dysphonia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia have a strained and strangled voice.

 

Explanation:


This statement is incorrect because patients with Abductor Type Dysphonia actually present with a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice, not a strained and strangled voice. The strained or strangled voice quality with phonation interruptions and voice breaks is characteristic of Adductor Dysphonia, where the adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to adduct excessively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a dystonia of the laryngeal muscles. This is true. Spasmodic dysphonia involves abnormal muscular contractions (spasms) of the laryngeal muscles during speech. The condition can involve either adductor or abductor muscles, causing different voice patterns.

 

Option B. Standard treatment is with injection of Botulinum Toxin. This is true. Botulinum toxin injections are the standard treatment for both adductor and abductor spasmodic dysphonia. In adductor type, injections target the thyroarytenoid muscle, while in abductor type, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are injected.

 

Option C. Multiple injections of Botulinum toxin are required. This is true. The benefit of botulinum toxin injections typically lasts only up to 16 weeks, after which repeat injections are needed. This makes it a recurring treatment rather than a one-time solution.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adductor and Abductor spasmodic dysphonias present with distinctly different voice qualities - strained/strangled in adductor type versus breathy in abductor type - though both are treated with botulinum toxin injections that require periodic repetition due to their temporary effect.
